transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Hello, and thank you for having me. I'm glad to be here and share my experiences. Please go ahead with your questions.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Of course. As I mentioned, I'm 52 years old and I live in suburban Seattle. I have a master's degree, and I used to work as an accountant until I retired. Since then, I've focused on staying healthy and active. I enjoy exercising regularly, whether it's going for walks or attending fitness classes. I’m widowed, which has had its challenges, but I try to maintain a positive outlook on life. I also have Medicare coverage, which gives me peace of mind when it comes to my healthcare needs. Overall, I'm in a good place, but I still carry some experiences from my past that shape how I view health and wellness.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Certainly. I had two pregnancies in my younger years. I was in my late twenties when I first found out I was pregnant with my first child. It was a mix of excitement and nerves, as it was a big change in my life. My second pregnancy followed a few years later. Unfortunately, I also experienced a miscarriage in between those two pregnancies, which was a difficult time for me. It made me more aware of the complexities of pregnancy and maternal health. Despite that hurdle, I was grateful to have two healthy deliveries afterward. I remember the prenatal care I received was generally good, and I felt well-supported during my pregnancies. Is there anything specific you'd like to know about those experiences?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I first sought prenatal care shortly after I confirmed my pregnancy with my first child, which was around the sixth or seventh week. I remember feeling a mix of excitement and anxiety as I made that appointment. The experience was overall positive. My healthcare provider was very supportive and took the time to explain everything to me - from what to expect during the pregnancy to the importance of regular check-ups and prenatal vitamins. I felt reassured by the information I received and the care I was given. 

For my second pregnancy, I sought care even earlier, as I was more informed and proactive. I remember feeling more confident in advocating for myself and asking questions. 

Can you tell me if there were any challenges you faced when accessing prenatal care, especially considering your past experiences?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I appreciate your interest in my experiences. However, since I am no longer pregnant and have not had any recent encounters with prenatal care providers, I don't have a current healthcare provider for prenatal care. But reflecting on my past pregnancies, I had a great relationship with my obstetrician during those times. 

They were very approachable and always encouraged me to ask questions, which I found comforting. I felt that they genuinely cared about my well-being and the health of my babies. They took the time to listen to my concerns and provided me with the necessary information to make informed decisions about my care. 

Looking back, I would say the relationship I had with my healthcare provider was one of trust and mutual respect. They helped me navigate through the excitement and anxiety that came with pregnancy, especially after experiencing a miscarriage. 

Is there anything else you would like to know about my past experiences with prenatal care or my healthcare relationships?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Persona: As I mentioned, I don't have current prenatal appointments since I'm not pregnant, but during my pregnancies, I typically had visits every four weeks during the first and early second trimester. As I progressed, those appointments became more frequent—every two weeks and then weekly as I approached my due date. 

A typical visit would start with checking my weight and blood pressure, which was important for monitoring my hypertension. Then, my healthcare provider would ask about any symptoms I was experiencing and how I was feeling overall. I appreciated that they took the time to listen and address any concerns I had.

After that, there would often be an ultrasound or other tests to monitor the baby's development, depending on how far along I was. I found those moments to be both thrilling and reassuring. My provider would discuss the results with me and explain what to expect moving forward. 

They also emphasized the importance of prenatal vitamins and nutrition, which I found helpful. I always left the appointments feeling informed and more confident about my pregnancy. 

If I ever had questions, I felt comfortable asking them during these visits, which I think is crucial for any patient-provider relationship. Do you want to know more about the types of questions I had or any specific aspects of my appointments?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I was fortunate to have relatively straightforward experiences, but I did face some health concerns. The most significant was managing my hypertension. I was diagnosed with it a few years before my pregnancies, so I was already aware of the importance of monitoring it closely. My healthcare provider was very attentive to this condition, and we worked together to ensure that it was well-controlled throughout both pregnancies. 

In addition to my hypertension, I had a history of a miscarriage, which made me particularly cautious and aware of any potential complications. I remember experiencing some anxiety related to that past experience, especially during the early stages of my pregnancies. However, my obstetrician was very supportive and helped me navigate those feelings.

I also had a past appendectomy, which was not directly related to my pregnancies, but I did discuss it with my healthcare provider to ensure that it wouldn’t pose any risks. They assured me that it should not impact my pregnancies.

Overall, while there were some health concerns, my pregnancies were managed well with the help of my healthcare team, and I was grateful for the support I received. Are there any specific complications or health issues you would like me to elaborate on?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I appreciate your understanding of my situation. Currently, I take a few medications to manage my health, particularly my hypertension. I'm on a low-dose antihypertensive medication that's been very effective in keeping my blood pressure well-controlled. 

In addition to that, I also take a daily multivitamin to support my overall health, as I believe that maintaining a balanced diet and being proactive about nutrition is important, especially as I age. Since I’m not pregnant, I’m not taking any prenatal vitamins at the moment, but I did during my pregnancies, which I found beneficial.

I also make it a point to stay hydrated and maintain a healthy diet, which includes plenty of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. It’s important to me to stay as healthy as possible. If there are any other specific aspects of my medication or supplement regimen you'd like to discuss, please let me know.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I was very mindful of my diet and nutrition. I understood that what I ate would directly impact not only my health but also the health of my baby. I made a conscious effort to consume a balanced diet rich in nutrients. 

I focused on incorporating a variety of foods into my meals. I aimed for plenty of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats. For instance, I enjoyed salads, whole grain breads, and lean meats like chicken and fish. I also made sure to include sources of calcium, such as yogurt and cheese, since building strong bones for my baby was important to me.

During my pregnancies, I followed my healthcare provider's advice and took prenatal vitamins, which included folic acid. I was aware that folic acid is crucial for preventing certain birth defects, and I wanted to ensure that I was doing everything I could for my baby's health.

I also tried to stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water, which I know is important during pregnancy. I paid attention to my body’s signals and made sure to eat when I was hungry, which sometimes meant having healthy snacks throughout the day.

Given my history of hypertension, I was cautious about my sodium intake as well. I worked to limit processed foods and opted for fresh ingredients whenever possible. Overall, I felt that maintaining a nutritious diet helped me feel better physically and gave me peace of mind during my pregnancies.

Is there anything specific you would like to know about my dietary choices or how I managed nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, my emotional experiences were quite varied. Initially, I felt a rush of excitement and joy when I learned I was pregnant. However, that joy was often mixed with anxiety, especially after my miscarriage. I was very conscious of my feelings and the potential for complications, which made me more sensitive during the early stages.

As the pregnancies progressed, I found that my anxiety lessened somewhat, especially once I felt the baby moving and could see positive developments during my ultrasounds. Those moments were incredibly reassuring and helped to alleviate some of my worries. However, I still had moments of doubt and concern, particularly regarding my hypertension and how it might affect my pregnancy.

I also experienced a range of emotions related to my support system. Being widowed meant that I sometimes felt alone during this journey, and I missed having my partner by my side. But I leaned heavily on my family and friends for support. They were there for me, which helped me cope with the emotional ups and downs. My healthcare provider's supportive approach also played a significant role in helping me manage my feelings. They encouraged me to express my concerns, which made me feel heard and validated.

Overall, while there were definitely challenges emotionally, I tried to focus on the positive aspects and the joy of bringing a new life into the world. I found comfort in taking care of myself and staying active, which helped improve my mood. If you’d like to know more about specific strategies I used to cope with my emotions or any particular experiences that stand out, please feel free to ask.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, my support network was incredibly important to me. Given that I was widowed, I had to rely on family and friends to provide the emotional and practical support I needed. My family, particularly my siblings and a few close friends, were my biggest pillars during this time. They would check in on me regularly, come over to spend time with me, and accompany me to some of my prenatal appointments, which was comforting.

My sister, in particular, was very involved. She had children of her own and was always ready to offer advice or just lend an empathetic ear when I needed to talk about my feelings or concerns. I also had a couple of friends who were either pregnant or had recently given birth, and we would share our experiences and support each other through the ups and downs.

In addition to my family and friends, my healthcare provider played a crucial role in my support system. Their reassurance and willingness to listen to my concerns helped me feel more secure throughout my pregnancies. They made it clear that I could reach out to them whenever I had questions or needed guidance, which was invaluable.

Overall, I felt fortunate to have a strong support network, even in the absence of my partner. Their love and encouragement helped me navigate the challenges of pregnancy, especially after experiencing a miscarriage. If you'd like to know more about any specific interactions or support strategies that were particularly helpful to me, just let me know.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I did think about my birth plan and what my preferences for delivery would be. For both of my pregnancies, I aimed for a natural vaginal delivery, as I felt more comfortable with that approach. I had previously attended a childbirth education class, which helped me understand what to expect and allowed me to prepare mentally and physically for the experience.

I preferred to have a calm and supportive environment during labor, so I discussed with my healthcare provider the possibility of having dim lighting and music in the delivery room to help create a soothing atmosphere. I also wanted to have my family members present, particularly my sister, who I knew would provide emotional support and encouragement.

In terms of pain management, I was open to using natural coping techniques like breathing exercises and movement, but I also understood the importance of being flexible. I wanted to keep my options open in case I needed medication for pain relief. My healthcare provider was very understanding of my wishes and emphasized that we could adapt the plan as needed based on how labor progressed.

Additionally, I had a strong desire for immediate skin-to-skin contact with my baby after delivery, as I had read about the benefits for bonding and breastfeeding. I believed that this would be an important part of my experience.

Overall, while I had my preferences, I also recognized that sometimes things don’t go as planned, and I was willing to be flexible for the safety and well-being of both myself and my baby. If you’d like to dive deeper into any specific aspects of my birth plan or my feelings about delivery, please feel free to ask.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I sought out a variety of sources to gather information about pregnancy and childbirth. I wanted to be as informed as possible, so I turned to both traditional and modern resources.

First and foremost, I relied heavily on my healthcare provider. They were an invaluable source of information, and I appreciated the time they took to answer my questions and provide guidance during my appointments. I made a point to write down any questions I had before each visit to ensure I didn't forget to ask them.

In addition to my healthcare provider, I read several books on pregnancy and childbirth. Some of my favorites included "What to Expect When You're Expecting," which provided a week-by-week guide to pregnancy, and "The Birth Partner," which helped me understand the labor process better and prepare for what to expect. These books offered practical advice and insights that I found comforting.

I also attended prenatal classes, which were beneficial both for the information shared and for meeting other expectant parents. The classes covered topics like nutrition, labor techniques, and breastfeeding, and they provided a supportive environment to ask questions and share experiences with others.

Online resources were another significant source of information for me. I visited reputable websites such as the American Pregnancy Association and the CDC's pregnancy page. I found forums and parenting blogs helpful for hearing personal stories and tips from other mothers, but I was careful to cross-reference any advice with trusted sources to ensure it was accurate.

Lastly, I leaned on my family and friends, particularly those who had already been through pregnancy and childbirth. Their personal experiences and advice were invaluable, and I appreciated their willingness to share.

Overall, I found that combining these various sources allowed me to feel well-prepared and informed throughout my pregnancies. If you’d like to delve into any specific resources or methods I used, please let me know!

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, managing the financial aspects was definitely a concern for me, especially since I was a widow and had to navigate everything on my own. I was fortunate to have a stable income as a retired accountant, which provided a solid financial foundation. However, I still took a careful approach to budgeting and planning for the expenses associated with having a baby.

First, I created a budget specifically for pregnancy-related costs. This included prenatal care visits, any necessary tests or ultrasounds, delivery expenses, and postpartum care. I worked closely with my healthcare provider to understand what services would be covered by my Medicare coverage, which helped me anticipate my out-of-pocket costs.

In addition to medical expenses, I also factored in costs for baby supplies, such as clothing, diapers, and nursery items. I was mindful of spending and often sought out second-hand items from friends or purchases at thrift stores. I found that many parents were willing to pass on gently used baby gear, which helped me save money while still preparing adequately for the arrival of my child.

I also considered the long-term financial aspects of raising a child, such as education savings. Although it felt like a long way off, I wanted to start thinking about how I could set aside funds for my children's future needs. I did some research on different savings plans and options for educational expenses.

Overall, while I was aware that having a baby comes with financial responsibilities, I felt confident in my ability to manage it, especially with the support of my family. They helped me find ways to save and even gifted me some essential items, which eased the financial burden a bit.

If you’d like to know more about specific financial strategies I used or any particular challenges I faced, please let me know!

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, my work situation was impacted quite a bit, but thankfully, I was retired by that time, which allowed me to focus fully on my health and preparing for the arrival of my babies. However, I can reflect on how my previous experience as an accountant and my work life prior to retirement influenced my outlook on pregnancy and motherhood.

When I was working, I remember feeling a sense of pressure to balance my professional responsibilities with my personal life, especially when I first became pregnant. I was fortunate to have a supportive employer and colleagues who understood the importance of family and health. My workplace provided maternity leave, which I appreciated, as it allowed me to take the necessary time off to care for myself and my newborn without the worry of job security.

Once I retired, I found that I had more time to prepare mentally and physically for my pregnancies. I was able to prioritize my health, attend prenatal appointments, and engage in activities that contributed to my well-being, such as exercising and attending prenatal classes. I also used this time to learn as much as I could about parenting and prepare my home for a new baby.

Being retired also provided me with the flexibility to manage my time better, which was a blessing during those demanding months of pregnancy. I could attend appointments without worrying about work commitments, and I felt more at ease preparing for childbirth and the arrival of my children.

Overall, while my pregnancies didn't directly affect my employment situation since I was already retired, they did significantly influence how I viewed work-life balance and the importance of self-care. If you'd like to explore any specific aspects of my work history or how it shaped my experiences during pregnancy, feel free to ask!

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I definitely took the time to think about the postpartum period and what I would need to do to care for myself and my baby once they arrived. I understood that the postpartum phase could be both physically and emotionally challenging, so I wanted to prepare as much as I could.

One of my primary concerns was ensuring that I had a support system in place. I planned to rely heavily on my family, especially my sister, who had experience with newborns. I knew she would be a great help in those early weeks, whether it was providing meals, helping with household tasks, or simply being there to lend an ear if I needed to talk.

I also considered my own self-care during this time. I recognized the importance of rest and recovery, especially after delivery. I planned to take it easy and allow myself the time I needed to heal, both physically and emotionally. To support this, I aimed to set up a comfortable space at home for myself and the baby, where I could rest and bond without too many distractions.

In terms of mental health, I was aware of the potential for postpartum depression and wanted to be proactive about my emotional well-being. I planned to stay in touch with my healthcare provider and keep them informed of how I was feeling. I also made a point to seek out local support groups for new mothers, as I thought it might be beneficial to connect with others experiencing similar challenges.

Financially, I considered the costs associated with postpartum care and baby supplies, such as diapers and formula, if needed. I wanted to have a budget in place to manage those expenses without added stress. 

Overall, I aimed to approach the postpartum period with a plan while remaining flexible, understanding that things might not go exactly as I hoped. If you have specific areas of the postpartum experience you’d like me to elaborate on, such as support strategies or self-care practices, please let me know!

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.
